focus_skills: Systems of two linear equations in two variables

questions.question: If <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>28</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Subtract 3 from both sides: <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. Then divide by 5: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving linear equations, always perform inverse operations in the reverse order of operations.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: At a bakery, a muffin costs <math><mi>$</mi><mn>2</mn></math> and a bagel costs <math><mi>$</mi><mn>3</mn></math>. If a customer buys 4 items and spends exactly <math><mi>$</mi><mn>10</mn></math>, how many bagels did the customer buy?
questions.explanation: Let <math><mi>m</mi></math> be muffins and <math><mi>b</mi></math> be bagels. <math><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> and <math><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. From the first, <math><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi></math>. Substitute: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mn>8</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math> → <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For word problems, define variables clearly and translate the conditions into equations before solving.

questions.question: Which of the following is equivalent to <math><mn>9</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Combine like terms: <math><mn>9</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi></math> and <math><mn>12</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, so <math><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When simplifying expressions, carefully combine only like terms (same variable and exponent).

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='200' fill='white'/><rect x='50' y='50' width='120' height='60' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><text x='50' y='45' font-size='14'>6 in</text><text x='175' y='80' font-size='14'>10 in</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A rectangle with length 10 inches and width 6 inches.
questions.question: The rectangle above has a length of <math><mn>10</mn></math> inches and a width of <math><mn>6</mn></math> inches. What is its area, in square inches?
questions.explanation: Area = length × width = <math><mn>10</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math> square inches.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='200' fill='white'/><rect x='50' y='50' width='120' height='60' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='lightblue'/><text x='50' y='45' font-size='14'>6 in</text><text x='175' y='80' font-size='14'>10 in</text><text x='110' y='35' font-size='16' fill='darkblue'>Area = 60 in²</text></svg>
questions.score_improvement_tip: For rectangle area, remember the formula A = l × w. Units are squared for area.

questions.question: The line <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math> passes through the point <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>m</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>: <math><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></math> → <math><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> → <math><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find the slope given a point and equation, plug the coordinates into the equation and solve.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add the two equations: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></math> → <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When both equations are in standard form, adding or subtracting them can eliminate a variable quickly.

questions.question: If <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, what is a possible value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Set each factor to zero: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>; <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Among options, <math><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></math> is possible.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the Zero Product Property: if a product equals zero, at least one factor must be zero.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: A car travels 240 miles on 8 gallons of gasoline. At the same rate, how many gallons would be needed to travel 360 miles?
questions.explanation: Miles per gallon: <math><mn>240</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math> mpg. For 360 miles: <math><mn>360</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> gallons.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For rate problems, find the unit rate first, then scale accordingly.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='200' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='150' x2='250' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='150' cy='150' r='2' fill='black'/><line x1='150' y1='150' x2='226' y2='85' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='150' y='170' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>A</text><text x='255' y='155' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='230' y='80' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='40' y='155' font-size='14'>D</text><path d='M 180 150 A 30 30 0 0 0 176 128' stroke='black' fill='none'/><text x='185' y='140' font-size='12'>50°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A horizontal straight line with points D, A, and B in that order from left to right. A ray AC extends upward and to the right from point A. The angle BAC is labeled 50°.
questions.question: In the figure above, line DB is intersected by ray AC at point A. If the measure of angle BAC is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>50</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the measure, in degrees, of angle CAD?
questions.explanation: Angles BAC and CAD form a linear pair on the straight line DB. Therefore, they are supplementary and their sum is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi><mo>∠</mo><mi>CAD</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>50</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>130</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='200' fill='white'/><line x1='50' y1='150' x2='250' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='150' cy='150' r='2' fill='black'/><line x1='150' y1='150' x2='226' y2='85' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='150' y='170' font-size='14' text-anchor='middle'>A</text><text x='255' y='155' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='230' y='80' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='40' y='155' font-size='14'>D</text><path d='M 180 150 A 30 30 0 0 0 176 128' stroke='black' fill='none'/><text x='185' y='140' font-size='12'>50°</text><path d='M 172 132 A 30 30 0 0 0 120 150' stroke='red' fill='none'/><text x='130' y='120' font-size='12' fill='red'>130°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same figure with the supplementary angle CAD highlighted in red and labeled 130°.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for linear pairs (angles forming a straight line); their sum is always 180°.

questions.question: If <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>≤</mo><mn>9</mn></math>, what is the greatest possible integer value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 7: <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. Divide by 4: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. The greatest integer ≤ 4 is 4.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Solve inequalities like equations, but remember to flip the sign if multiplying or dividing by a negative.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: The sum of two numbers is <math><mn>47</mn></math>. Their difference is <math><mn>15</mn></math>. What is the larger number?
questions.explanation: Let the numbers be <math><mi>a</mi></math> and <math><mi>b</mi></math>, <math><mi>a</mi><mo>></mo><mi>b</mi></math>. <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>47</mn></math> and <math><mi>a</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>. Add the equations: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>62</mn></math> → <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>31</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For 'sum and difference' problems, adding the equations gives twice the larger; subtracting gives twice the smaller.

questions.question: The function <math><mi>f</mi></math> is defined by <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. For what value of <math><mi>x</mi></math> does <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Set <math><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find input given output, substitute the output into the function and solve for the variable.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>y</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve by elimination. Multiply second equation by 3: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Subtract the first equation: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>17</mn></math> → <math><mn>7</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>14</mn></math> → <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When eliminating a variable, align equations so that adding or subtracting cancels one variable.

questions.question: If <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, what is the sum of the solutions?
questions.explanation: Factor: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Solutions: <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Sum = <math><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a quadratic ax² + bx + c = 0, the sum of roots is -b/a, even without factoring.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='200' fill='white'/><polygon points='80,150 200,150 200,100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><polyline points='190,150 190,140 200,140' stroke='black' fill='none'/><path d='M 100 150 A 20 20 0 0 0 98 142' stroke='black' fill='none'/><text x='65' y='160' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='205' y='95' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='205' y='165' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='120' y='145' font-size='14'>x°</text><text x='140' y='170' font-size='14'>12</text><text x='210' y='130' font-size='14'>5</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right-angled triangle ABC with the right angle at C. The horizontal leg AC is labeled 12. The vertical leg BC is labeled 5. The angle at vertex A is labeled x°.
questions.question: In the right triangle ABC shown, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. What is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation:
To find <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo><mo>)</mo></math>, identify the sides relative to angle A. 
The side opposite angle A is BC, which has a length of 5. 
The side adjacent to angle A is AC, which has a length of 12. 
Using the tangent ratio: 
<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>°</mo><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>opposite</mi><mi>adjacent</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='200' fill='white'/><polygon points='80,150 200,150 200,100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='#f0f8ff'/><polyline points='190,150 190,140 200,140' stroke='black' fill='none'/><text x='65' y='160' font-size='14'>A</text><text x='205' y='95' font-size='14'>B</text><text x='205' y='165' font-size='14'>C</text><text x='120' y='170' font-size='14' fill='blue'>Adjacent = 12</text><text x='210' y='130' font-size='14' fill='red'>Opposite = 5</text><text x='120' y='145' font-size='14'>x°</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same right triangle with side AC labeled 'Adjacent = 12' and side BC labeled 'Opposite = 5'.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall SOH CAH TOA: Tangent is Opposite over Adjacent. Identify the legs based on the angle in question.

questions.question: A shirt originally costs <math><mi>$</mi><mn>60</mn></math>. Its price is increased by <math><mn>25</mn><mo>%</mo></math>, then decreased by <math><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. What is the final price?
questions.explanation: After 25% increase: <math><mn>60</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1.25</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>75</mn></math>. After 20% decrease: <math><mn>75</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.80</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For successive percent changes, multiply by (1 + increase) and (1 − decrease). Order matters if values differ.

questions.skill: Systems of two linear equations in two variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>5</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn></math> and <math><mn>3</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Multiply second equation by 2: <math><mn>6</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>. Add to first equation: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>18</mn></math> → <math><mn>11</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></math> → <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>50</mn><mn>11</mn></mfrac></math>. Substitute into second equation: <math><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mn>50</mn><mn>11</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math> → <math><mfrac><mn>150</mn><mn>11</mn></mfrac><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math> → <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>150</mn><mn>11</mn></mfrac><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>99</mn><mn>11</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>51</mn><mn>11</mn></mfrac></math>. Then <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>50</mn><mn>11</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>51</mn><mn>11</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>101</mn><mn>11</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For systems, sometimes solving for a combination like a+b directly is faster than finding a and b separately.

questions.question: If <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math>, what is one possible value of <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Set equal: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math> → <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> → <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> or <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Among options, 3 is possible.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For systems with linear and quadratic equations, substitute and solve the resulting quadratic.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: The mean of five numbers is <math><mn>12</mn></math>. If one of the numbers is removed, the mean of the remaining four is <math><mn>10</mn></math>. What is the value of the number removed?
questions.explanation: Sum of 5 numbers = <math><mn>5</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn></math>. Sum of 4 numbers = <math><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn></math>. Removed number = <math><mn>60</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use mean × count = total sum to find missing values in data sets.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='200' fill='white'/><circle cx='150' cy='100' r='60' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><line x1='150' y1='100' x2='210' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='150' cy='100' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='135' y='95' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>O</text><text x='175' y='90' font-size='14'>6</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center labeled O. A horizontal radius extends to the right and is labeled with a length of 6.
questions.question: A circle has center <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi></math> and radius <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>6</mn></math>. What is the circumference of the circle?
questions.explanation:
The formula for the circumference of a circle is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi></math>. 
Substituting the given radius <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>: 
<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='200' viewBox='0 0 300 200' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='200' fill='white'/><circle cx='150' cy='100' r='60' stroke='blue' stroke-width='3' fill='#fdfdfd'/><line x1='150' y1='100' x2='210' y2='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='150' cy='100' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='135' y='95' font-size='14' font-family='serif' font-style='italic'>O</text><text x='175' y='90' font-size='14'>r=6</text><text x='150' y='185' font-size='16' fill='blue' text-anchor='middle'>C = 2π(6) = 12π</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The circle with the circumference highlighted in blue. The calculation C = 2π(6) = 12π is displayed below the circle.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize the circumference formula: C = 2πr (or C = πd). Don't confuse it with Area = πr².
